title-group.article-title: Promoting toddlers’ self-regulation and healthy eating habits among families living in poverty: A randomized controlled trial of Recipe 4 Success

article-meta.aff: 3Pennsylvania State University, State College, Pennsylvania, USA
4West Virginia University, Morgantown, West Virginia, USA

fn.p: Present address: Cheryl B. McNeil, University of Florida, Gainesville, Florida, USA, Ye Rang Park, University of Oklahoma-Tulsa, Tulsa, Oklahoma, USA, Christina N. Kim, New York University, New York City, New York, USA, Vivian L. Tamkin, Santa Clara University, Santa Clara, California, USA

author-notes.corresp: Correspondence: Robert L. Nix, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA. robert.nix@wisc.edu

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-NoDerivs License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non-commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

abstract.p: The Recipe 4 Success preventive intervention targeted multiple factors critical to the health and well-being of toddlers living in poverty. This randomized controlled trial, which was embedded within Early Head Start home visits for 12 weeks, included 242 racially and ethnically diverse families (51% girls; toddler mean age = 2.58 years; data collected 2016–2019). Compared to parents in usual practice home visits, parents in Recipe 4 Success displayed greater sensitive scaffolding of toddlers’ learning and more responsive food parenting practices (Cohen’s d = .21–.30). Toddlers in Recipe 4 Success exhibited greater self-regulation and had healthier eating habits (Cohen’s d = |.16–.35|). Results highlight the value of Recipe 4 Success in promoting parent and toddler behavior change that could have life-long benefits.

body.p: One of the most insidious aspects of growing up in poverty is that it tends to undermine those factors most predictive of health and well-being across the lifespan (Chaudry & Wimer, 2016). For example, growing up in poverty affects early brain development, which is related to academic achievement and, eventually, socioeconomic status (Hair et al., 2015). Because children living in poverty are more likely to be from marginalized racial and ethnic groups, the effects of poverty and the effects of structural racism on health and well-being are often compounded (Iruka et al., 2022; Shonkoff et al., 2021). While we work toward redressing systemic inequities, it is critical to simultaneously do everything possible to help support children growing up in poverty, so they receive the care they need and develop the skills required to navigate the challenges they face.

This study tested the efficacy of the Recipe 4 Success preventive intervention, which was designed to enhance the benefits of Early Head Start, an evidence-based home visits program which is implemented across the United States and intended to help families living in poverty nurture the social-emotional and physical health of their infants and toddlers (Love et al., 2005). Recipe 4 Success sought to capitalize on the inter-related and mutually reinforcing ways in which parents could engage in greater sensitive scaffolding and more responsive food parenting practices as a means of promoting toddlers’ self-regulation and healthy eating habits.

sec.title: Parents’ sensitive scaffolding
sec.p: Parents’ sensitive scaffolding involves understanding the developmental tasks individual children are attempting to master and structuring interactions to facilitate success with maximum autonomy (Pendergrast & MacPhee, 2018). Sensitive scaffolding depends on parents’ knowledge of children’s skills and a moment-by-moment assessment of their progress, level of engagement, and the likelihood of imminent frustration. As parents attend to those factors, they often use language to direct attention and orchestrate problem solving, so children are able to remain in an ever-shifting zone of proximal development. Parents’ sensitive scaffolding appears critically important to the development of multiple aspects of children’s self-regulation, including executive functions, emotion regulation skills, and behavioral control (Hoffman et al., 2006; Hughes & Ensor, 2009).

Living in poverty and experiencing other sources of stress can make it more challenging for parents to provide sensitive scaffolding and exhibit high levels of responsiveness (Magnuson & Duncan, 2019). Compared to parents from middle- and upper income families, parents in living in poverty often speak to their children less and ask fewer questions to guide their learning (Schwab & Lew-Williams, 2016). This can affect the development of children’s language skills, a robust predictor of growth in self-regulation (Vallotton & Ayoub, 2011). Relatedly, parents living in poverty tend to use more prohibitions with their children and provide fewer affirmations (Hart & Risley, 1995), which can be detrimental to children’s sense of autonomy and self-regulation.

sec.title: Responsive food parenting practices
sec.p: Responsive food parenting practices are a domain-specific form of sensitive scaffolding. Food parenting practices represent the strategies parents use to introduce new foods and to encourage their toddlers and young children to eat what is good for them. Ideally, parents create a food environment in which toddlers can be granted maximum autonomy in choosing what to eat among healthy options (Sano et al., 2019). The ways parents interact with toddlers and young children can either support or negatively impact self-regulation around food (Balantekin et al., 2020). When parents establish consistent routines and involve children in the preparation of meals and snacks, children are more likely to develop healthy eating habits (Knai et al., 2006). In contrast, when parents are coercive and controlling around food, children may become less reliant on their own feelings of hunger and satiety, leading to dysregulated eating and excessive weight gain (Vollmer & Mobley, 2013).

As with sensitive scaffolding, living in poverty makes it more challenging for parents to enact responsive food parenting practices as a means of promoting toddlers’ healthy eating habits (Sano et al., 2019). When faced with food insecurity, parents may be most focused on simply ensuring their children eat and are not hungry (Arlinghaus & Laska, 2021).

sec.title: Toddlers’ self-regulation
sec.p: Self-regulation allows us to control responses and actions in ways that are adaptive and help achieve long-term goals (Blair & Ku, 2022). Self-regulation occurs at both psychological and physiological levels and includes the distinct but related abilities to direct and sustain attention, inhibit impulses, plan and sequence actions, and adhere to healthy eating routines. Self-regulation grows rapidly around age 2 (Calkins, 2007), enabled in part by the development of the prefrontal cortex (Hodel, 2018). Greater self-regulation in early childhood predicts competence in multiple domains of functioning in adolescence, including executive functions, academic achievement, stress management, and social-emotional skills (Robson et al., 2020). Greater self-regulation in early childhood is also associated with multiple dimensions of success in adulthood, including better physical health, less substance abuse, higher levels of education, greater income, and fewer arrests (Moffitt et al., 2011). In addition to being related to cognitive and social-emotional functioning, there is some—albeit, not always consistent—evidence that self-regulation is related to body mass index (BMI) and obesity (Robson et al., 2020). For example, children who had difficulties with one aspect of self-regulation, effortful control, at age 3 had a higher BMI through age 12 (Francis & Susman, 2009).

Unfortunately, living in poverty puts children at risk for lower levels of psychological and physiological self-regulation. The chronic stress associated with living in poverty appears to affect development in regions of the brain most critical to self-regulation (Palacios-Barrios & Hanson, 2019). For young children, much of the relation between chronic stress and lower levels of self-regulation appears to be mediated by less positive parent–child interactions (Yu et al., 2020). However, that relation also can be moderated by high levels of parents’ sensitivity and warmth (Blair & Ku, 2022).

sec.title: Healthy eating habits
sec.p: Just as responsive food parenting practices are a domain-specific form of parents’ sensitive scaffolding, healthy eating habits, which involve modulating prepotent preferences for energy-dense foods in favor of nutrient-dense foods, represent one aspect of self-regulation. According to the American Academy of Pediatrics, toddlers’ diets should consist of small portions of a variety of fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and sources of protein (https://www.aap.org/en-us/advocacy-and-policy/aap-health-initiatives/HALF-Implementation-Guide/Age-Specific-Content/Pages/Toddler-Food-and-Feeding.aspx). Parents are advised to limit the availability of foods and drinks that are overly processed or high in salt or sugar, such as hot dogs, chips, desserts, and soda. Like other aspects of self-regulation, deliberate self-regulation around eating appears to emerge around age 2, when taste preferences are being formed (Birch & Ventura, 2009). Children who develop healthy eating habits during this period are likely to grow into adults with healthy eating habits (Craigie et al., 2011).

However, due to multiple structural and environmental impediments, toddlers living in poverty are often less likely to develop healthy eating habits. For example, food deserts are more prevalent in communities with lower average incomes, especially when those communities also have a high proportion of residents of color (Karpyn et al., 2019). In food deserts, the most accessible and least expensive foods, such as those available at fast food restaurants or convenience stores, tend to be high in calories but low in essential nutrients (Fleishhacker et al., 2011).

sec.title: An integrated approach to intervention: Recipe 4 Success
sec.p: The toddler period represents an ideal time in which to intentionally support and promote the development of both self-regulation and healthy eating habits. Although systematic reviews have identified relatively few preventive interventions that reliably change toddlers’ self-regulation or healthy eating habits (Morawska et al., 2019; Murray et al., 2015), those interventions that are effective often focus on parents’ behaviors related to sensitive scaffolding and/or responsive food parenting practices. For example, in the Playing and Learning Strategies intervention, parents learn to read children’s signals, respond contingently, provide choices, build and maintain children’s attention, and use rich language (Landry et al., 2008). In an adapted version of Active Parenting, implemented as home visits with Native American families, parents who established mealtime and active play routines, guided positive choices, and modeled desired eating behaviors were successful in reversing children’s unhealthy weight gain (Harvey-Berino & Rourke, 2003). In Family Check-Up, parents who were given extensive feedback about their families and had the opportunity to receive additional parenting and family management support from family consultants demonstrated more positive interactions with their toddlers, who, in turn, had decreased behavior problems over time (Dishion et al., 2008). In Parent-Corps, parents who participated in a school readiness program designed to support family engagement and child social-emotional learning were better able to use evidence-based strategies to create safe, nurturing, and predictable home environments, leading their children to have greater academic achievement and better mental health over time (Brotman et al., 2016; Dawson-McClure et al., 2015). Interestingly, although neither Family Check-Up nor ParentCorps focused on healthy eating habits, both preventive interventions had a delayed impact on children’s overweight and obesity (Brotman et al., 2012; Smith et al., 2015).

The Recipe 4 Success preventive intervention was the result of a community-based participatory research collaboration involving university researchers and Early Head Start directors, clinical supervisors, nutrition educators, and home visitors (Nix, 2020). It sought to address the pressing need to develop and refine strategies to promote toddlers’ self-regulation and healthy eating habits by helping parents become proficient in sensitive scaffolding and responsive food parenting practices. Recipe 4 Success aimed to accomplish its goals by implementing within Early Head Start home visits an integrated curriculum that relied on active coaching strategies during parent and toddler cooking and food preparation activities. In a small randomized controlled trial (N = 73), Recipe 4 Success produced statistically significant improvements in four target outcomes most likely to be affected by living in poverty and most likely to shift developmental trajectories toward more optimal adjustment: parents’ sensitive scaffolding, Cohen’s d = .58; responsive food parenting practices, d = .87; toddlers’ self-regulation, d = .95; and healthy eating habits, d = .57 (Nix et al., 2021).

sec.title: The present study
sec.p: The present study reports the results of the second randomized controlled trial of Recipe 4 Success. Compared to the first trial, this trial included more families from more Early Head Start centers in both more rural and more urban communities, and it featured a more refined version of the curriculum. Because this trial attempts to replicate the positive findings from our first trial and was preregistered, this study should be viewed as more confirmatory on the continuum from exploratory investigations to confirmatory hypothesis testing. We hypothesized that, compared to parents in usual practice Early Head Start home visits, parents randomized to participate in Recipe 4 Success would exhibit more sensitive scaffolding and responsive food parenting practices. Likewise, we hypothesized that, compared to toddlers in usual practice Early Head Start home visits, toddlers in Recipe 4 Success would display greater self-regulation and have healthier eating habits.

sec.title: METHOD
sec.p: This study was preregistered at clinicaltrials.gov (NCT03958214) and was approved by the Institutional Review Boards of the University of Wisconsin-Madison and Pennsylvania State University. A timeline of all study activities is provided in Figure S1. A CONSORT diagram of participant enrollment, allocation, follow-up, and analysis is provided in Figure S2. Data were collected 2016–2019.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: This study included 242 parents and their toddlers. Thirty-seven percent of families were White, 25% were Black, 19% were Latinx, 17% were multiracial, 2% were Asian American, and less than 1% were Native American. Ninety-one percent of caregivers were mothers, 5% were fathers, and 4% were other relatives, all of whom are referred to as “parents” hereafter. Forty-seven percent of parents were single and did not live with a partner. Sixty-five percent had a high school degree or less; 60% did not work outside the home; 20% had a part-time job; and 20% had a full-time job. Sixty-nine percent of families lived below the federal poverty threshold, and an additional 25% of families lived below 200% of that threshold; the median family income was $1555 per month, and the median income-to-needs ratio was 0.75.
Among the toddlers in this study, 51% were girls, and 49% were boys. At the beginning of this study, they were age 2.58 years on average (SD = 0.31; range = 1.72–3.29).

sec.title: Recruitment and random assignment
sec.p: Families were recruited through organizations providing Early Head Start home visit services in seven cities, towns, and rural areas across Wisconsin and Pennsylvania. To be eligible for the study, families had to be able to complete assessments in English and have a toddler, age 2. (Note: There were some misunderstandings about trial guidelines regarding toddler age, causing some toddlers to fall outside the intended range.) Families’ Early Head Start home visitors told them about the study. If parents wanted to learn more, project staff members provided details and obtained consent. About 65% of eligible families chose to participate in the study.

Once families completed the baseline assessment, they were randomly assigned to receive the Recipe 4 Success preventive intervention, delivered by their regular Early Head Start home visitors during their regularly scheduled home visits, or continue to receive their usual practice Early Head Start home visits, which were structured around evidence-based curricula, such as Parents as Teachers (Wagner et al., 2002), and focused on cognitive and social-emotional skills, motor development, physical health, and positive parent–child relationships. Families who participated in Recipe 4 Success did not receive extra home visits or extra-long home visits. Rather, the content of Recipe 4 Success comprised an alternative means of meeting all the performance standards of usual practice Early Head Start home visits during the toddler years.

Families were assigned to condition on a 1:1 allocation, within the caseload of each home visitor, based on a coin toss conducted by the project manager. Across the recruitment period, 123 and 119 families were assigned to the intervention and control conditions, respectively.

sec.title: Intervention procedures
sec.p: Intended to be implemented in 12 consecutive weeks, the Recipe 4 Success preventive intervention consisted of carefully sequenced and highly structured food preparation lessons, which provided countless opportunities for parents to practice sensitive scaffolding and learn responsive food parenting practices and for toddlers to practice self-regulation—such as mixing carefully without spilling and waiting patiently for something to cook—and be exposed to new healthy foods. Each lesson required about 45 min of a regular 90-min home visit.

To introduce the curriculum, the first two Recipe 4 Success lessons used wooden food toys to help parents learn and practice four core parenting skills, adapted from parent–child interaction therapy (McNeil & Hembree-Kigin, 2010): describing toddlers’ behavior to maintain focus and concentration; reflecting and expanding on what toddlers said to demonstrate interest and promote language development; providing specific praise for persistence and effort; and giving meaningful concrete choices to foster investment and autonomy. Parents were told that cooking with toddlers was difficult, but these four core parenting skills would help their toddlers pay attention and enjoy the activity so they could be successful. Our goal was to help parents see how routine daily activities, like cooking, could become a way to spend high-quality special time with their toddlers.
In the subsequent 10 Recipe 4 Success lessons, home visitors coached families through actual food preparation activities, following a standard lesson protocol:

list-item.p: Check-in about practice during the prior week
Brief information about some aspect of self-regulation or healthy eating
A short physical activity for the child as a means of expending excess energy and increasing the ability to focus
Prepare a snack or meal following a simple recipe
A moment of mindfulness and gratitude statement before eating
Share the prepared meal or snack together
Additional brief information about self-regulation or healthy eating
Create a plan for generalization of lesson content across the coming week
Reflect on and evaluate what was learned during the current lesson
Home visitor, parent, and toddler clean-up

sec.p: All recipes were easy to prepare and featured 3–5 low-cost ingredients we supplied but that were listed on the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children (WIC) shopping guide for Wisconsin and Pennsylvania. The recipes always included at least one fruit and/or vegetable and a source of protein. Recipes never required anything more than a microwave or freezer to prepare. At the beginning of the intervention, families received toddler chef hats and aprons, a microwave-safe bowl, and a set of measuring cups and spoons. Lessons were tailored as necessary to accommodate food allergies or limited cooking facilities.

Before the start of the intervention, all home visitors completed a 2-day training conducted by study investigators. While implementing Recipe 4 Success, home visitors participated in a weekly 30-min group conference call with a study investigator to discuss the progress of lessons and address unexpected challenges. Home visitors also continued to receive ongoing supervision with their individual clinical supervisors.

Intervention fidelity was assessed via digital audio recordings of entire home visits that included Recipe 4 Success Lessons 4, 7, and 10. These recordings were collected by the home visitors, but rated by a team of laboratory-based research assistants who completed extensive training, reviewed multiple practice recordings, used a written manual, and participated in weekly group supervision discussions. On average, home visitors implemented 9 of the 12 essential components of Recipe 4 Success, such as reviewed educational information on self-regulation, prompted parent to use each of the core parenting behaviors, and set up plan with parent to practice new skills. Extensive ratings of the quality of delivery demonstrated that almost all lessons were high in educational content, home visitor therapeutic skills, home visitor–parent working alliance, and parent and toddler engagement.

sec.title: Assessment protocol
sec.p: Baseline assessments were conducted about 1 week prior to implementing the first Recipe 4 Success lesson, and post-intervention assessments were conducted at least 1 week after the final Recipe 4 Success lesson. The baseline and postintervention assessments required about 90 min to complete, and families were compensated $75 each time.

A diverse team of 10 project interviewers who were unaware of study condition conducted all assessments in families’ homes. Project interviewers were selected for their experience and ability to establish rapport with both parents and toddlers. They completed extensive training of study procedures and participated in ongoing supervision.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: The assessment battery relied on multiple informants and utilized well-validated methods and scales. The baseline and post-intervention assessments were virtually identical in content.

sec.title: Parents’ sensitive scaffolding
sec.p: This study included three measures of parents’ sensitive scaffolding, all assessed during three 3-min structured interactions in which parents and toddlers worked together on unfamiliar tasks, including bowling with a stuffed ball and pins, building a 4-foot-high tower with different-sized blocks, and completing a shape sorter ball puzzle in which parents could not touch individual pieces. All interactions were video recorded and independently coded by at least two members of a team of lab-based research assistants, who were unaware of study condition. The research assistants completed extensive training, reviewed multiple practice videos, used a written manual, and participated in weekly group supervision discussions of ratings. After computing reliability, all ratings for each task were averaged across the research assistants, except in the cases of large 2- or 3-point discrepancies (depending on the number of response options within a scale), when the research assistants rewatched videos to achieve consensus. The ratings from each of the three tasks were then averaged for final scores.

The first measure of parents’ sensitive scaffolding assessed how often parents used the four core parenting skills hypothesized to promote toddlers’ self-regulation and sustained attention/persistence, namely describing their toddlers’ behavior, reflecting and expanding on what their toddlers said, providing specific praise, and giving concrete choices (McNeil & Hembree-Kigin, 2010), with 0 = none, 1 = once, and 2 = twice or more, as parents rarely demonstrated each behavior more than twice in each task (intraclass correlation coefficient [ICC] for the four ratings on each of the three tasks = .72–.87; α [of those 12 total ratings] = .76).

The second measure of sensitive scaffolding assessed how often parents exhibited seven learning support behaviors, such as teaching concepts/facts, gently quizzing what toddlers already knew, involvement, teamwork, and collaboration (Bierman et al., 2015), with response options ranging from 1 = almost never to 5 = almost always (ICC = .62–.91; α = .89).

The third measure assessed technical scaffolding in general and represented how well parents structured each of the three tasks to simultaneously promote toddlers’ success and maximum independence (Hoffman et al., 2006), with response options ranging from 1 = parent exhibits characteristic ineffectiveness to 5 = parent exhibits characteristic effectiveness and meets the child’s needs almost the entire time (ICC = .76–.79; α = .71).

sec.title: Responsive food parenting practices
sec.p: This study included two measures of responsive food parenting practices, assessed during a shared snack when parents introduced two novel healthy foods, such as dried seaweed or prunes, to their toddlers. All interactions were video recorded by project interviewers and independently coded by yet another team of lab-based research assistants, who were unaware of study condition, completed extensive training, and participated in ongoing supervision.

The first measure of food parenting practices reflected the presence or absence of 10 responsive and noncoercive strategies that were most likely to arouse curiosity and interest in healthy food, such as modeling the enjoyment of the new food, and least likely to be associated with child obesity, such as not pressuring the toddler to eat something they clearly did not want (Vollmer & Mobley, 2013), with 0 = parent did not exhibit behavior and 1 = parent exhibited behavior (ICC = .73–.88).

The second measure was a rating of overall sensitivity, reflecting warmth, acceptance, and willingness to follow toddlers’ lead about what they did or did not want to eat, with response options ranging from 1 = not at all to 5 = very much (ICC = .84).

sec.title: Toddlers’ self-regulation
sec.p: This study included four measures of behaviors related to toddlers’ self-regulation. The first measure was the well-validated snack delay task (Kochanska et al., 2000). The project interviewer placed a single M&M on a plate and told the toddlers they could eat it, once time was up. The task consisted of four increasingly long trials, lasting 5, 15, 30, and 60 s, with individual scores of 0 = ate M&M before time was up and 1 = waited full time.

The second measure of toddlers’ self-regulation was the task orientation/regulation subscale of the Infant Behavior Record (Bayley, 1969; Stifter & Corey, 2001). After completing the full in-home assessment battery, project interviewers rated toddlers’ interest in engaging with and mastering new challenges, with response options ranging from 1 = does not indicate interest in objects to 9 = reluctantly relinquishes test materials. Project interviewers also rated toddlers’ attention, with response options ranging from 1 = fleeting attention to 9 = long continued absorption. The two ratings were then averaged for a total score (r = .59, p < .001).

The third measure of toddlers’ self-regulation assessed behavioral control with the compliance subscale of the well-validated Infant-Toddler Social and Emotional Assessment (Carter et al., 2003). Parents rated eight items, such as “Obeys when asked to stop being aggressive,” on a 3-point Likert scale, with response options ranging from 1 = not true/rarely to 3 = very true/often (α = .66).

The fourth measure comprised the dysregulation subscale of the Infant-Toddler Social and Emotional Assessment (Carter et al., 2003). Parents rated 13 items about negative emotionality, such as “Has trouble calming down when upset,” nine items about eating problems, such as “Picky eater,” and five items about sleep problems, such as “Has trouble falling asleep or staying asleep,” on a 3-point Likert scale, with response options ranging from 1 = not true/rarely to 3 = very true/often (α = .88).

sec.title: Healthy eating habits
sec.p: Finally, this study included three measures related to toddlers’ healthy eating habits. Two of these measures were derived from three 24-h recalls about what toddlers had done throughout the day, with one recall collected in person and two over the telephone (Nix et al., 2021). During the recalls, project interviewers guided parents through specific questions about what toddlers had eaten and drank for breakfast, morning snack, lunch, afternoon snack, dinner, and evening snack, with an additional opportunity for parents to identify foods not remembered initially. Project interviewers wrote down parents’ responses verbatim, and foods were later sorted into categories.
The first measure of healthy eating habits represented the percentage of days in which toddlers were involved in preparing one of their meals or snacks (Knai et al., 2006).

The second measure was composed of three items: (1) the percentage of all meals and snacks across the 3 days that included a fruit, not counting juice; (2) the percentage of meals and snacks that included a vegetable, not counting French fries; and (3) the percentage of meals and snacks that included a substantial source of protein, such as meat, poultry, fish, dairy, or peanut butter (Nix et al., 2021). All percentages were standardized and averaged for a total score.

The final measure related to healthy eating habits was BMI. Project interviewers measured toddlers’ weight on a high-quality portable scale, and height as they stood against a wall. These measurements were then used to calculate the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention sex-specific BMI-for-age percentile scores. Unlike the other outcomes in this study in which, at least conceptually, all parents and toddlers could improve in the same way, the effects of healthy eating habits should be quite different for toddlers with underweight, normal weight, and overweight/obesity. But, because Recipe 4 Success was a primary preventive intervention, not a clinical trial in which toddlers were screened for overweight/obesity, it included many toddlers who would not benefit from a lower BMI. Thus, postintervention BMI-for-age percentile scores were only examined among the toddlers who were at risk and had overweight/obesity at baseline (i.e., at or above the 85th percentile; n = 103).

sec.title: Plan of analysis
sec.p: The plan of analysis for this trial followed what was described in the original grant application to the National Institutes of Health. For each outcome, a hierarchical linear model was estimated with a random intercept to account for the nesting of families within home visitors’ caseloads. For those outcomes in which clustered variance at the home visitor level was so negligible it could not be estimated, results are comparable to those from a regression equation. In each hierarchical linear model, the independent variables were the indicator of intervention condition, the baseline measure of the outcome, Early Head Start site, race and ethnicity, toddler age, toddler gender, parent marital status, parent education, and whether the parent was employed. To assess robustness, all hierarchical linear models were re-estimated with the independent variables comprising only intervention condition and the baseline measure of the outcome, which was the lone covariate consistently related to parent and toddler outcomes. All parent and toddler outcomes were standardized with M = 0 and SD = 1.00, so the β of the intervention effect was comparable to Cohen’s d, representing the difference in standard deviation units between families in Recipe 4 Success and usual practice Early Head Start home visits, controlling for model covariates (Lorah, 2018).

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: Among the 242 families in this study, 229 families (95% of the original sample) were retained at postintervention. Attrition did not vary by any known and measured factors, including intervention condition, Early Head Start site, race/ethnicity, toddler age, toddler gender, parent marital status, parent education, and whether the parent was employed.

Baseline and postintervention means of all study outcomes for families in Recipe 4 Success and usual practice Early Head Start home visits are presented in Table 1. At baseline, there were three statistically significant differences between intervention groups: Compared to parents randomized to usual practice Early Head Start home visits, parents randomized to Recipe 4 Success initially displayed more of the core parenting behaviors, higher levels of learning support, and greater technical scaffolding. There were no statistically significant differences between intervention groups on the two outcome measures related to responsive food parenting practices, the four outcome measures related to toddlers’ self-regulation, or the three outcome measures related to healthy eating habits.

Postintervention correlations among outcomes, as well as with the baseline covariates, are presented in Table S1. Most of these correlations were small to moderate in size, suggesting that most outcomes were conceptually and empirically distinct from one another, representing different aspects of parent and toddler functioning.

sec.title: Recipe 4 Success intervention effects
sec.p: Intervention effects are summarized in Table 2, with full results of each hierarchical linear model presented in Tables S2–S13. The pattern of results was quite similar when the hierarchical linear models included all covariates, as summarized below, or only the baseline measure of the outcome, as can be seen in those tables.

Compared to parents who continued to receive usual practice Early Head Start home visits and controlling for baseline scores and family demographic characteristics, parents who participated in the Recipe 4 Success preventive intervention generalized the four core parenting behaviors hypothesized to support toddlers’ self-regulation and were more likely to apply them in the context of novel parent–child interaction tasks, standardized β = .30 (p = .021). As with Cohen’s d, this intervention effect indicates that parents in the two experimental conditions differed by three-tenths of a standard deviation, which would be considered a small-to-medium intervention effect size. Compared to control group parents, intervention parents also were more likely to provide their toddlers with higher levels of learning support as they mastered the new skills involved in those interaction tasks, standardized β = .26 (p = .031). Compared to control group parents, intervention parents displayed greater technical scaffolding of their children’s development in general, but this difference did not reach the conventional level of statistical significance for a two-tailed test, standardized β=.21, (p=.098).

In addition, Recipe 4 Success had a positive impact on responsive food parenting practices. Compared to control group parents, intervention parents were observed to engage in more responsive food parenting strategies that are associated with healthy eating habits and fewer coercive food parenting strategies associated with overweight/obesity, standardized β = .29 (p = .024). Overall, compared to control group parents, intervention parents were more sensitive in the way they interacted with their toddlers during the shared snack and more respectful of their toddlers’ autonomy, standardized β = .27 (p = .038).

As hypothesized, participating in Recipe 4 Success had a positive impact on toddlers’ self-regulation. Compared to toddlers who continued to receive usual practice Early Head Start home visits, toddlers who participated in Recipe 4 Success with their families were better able to resist temptation in the presence of highly desirable food rewards, standardized β = .31 (p = .012); they displayed greater task orientation and attention, as observed by project interviewers, standardized β = .25 (p = .046); they exhibited greater behavioral control and were more compliant, as perceived by their parents, standardized β = .20 (p = .040); and they had lower levels of dysregulation, in terms of negative emotionality and eating and sleeping problems, as perceived by their parents, standardized β = −.16 (p = .045).

Participating in Recipe 4 Success also had a positive impact on healthy eating habits. Compared to control group toddlers, intervention toddlers were more likely to help prepare their meals and snacks on a daily basis, standardized β = .33 (p = .007). Compared to control groups toddlers, intervention toddlers were more likely to eat healthy foods for meals and snacks, standardized β = .26 (p = .028). Finally, compared to control group toddlers with overweight/obesity at baseline (n = 58), intervention toddlers with overweight/obesity at baseline (n = 45) were more likely to have a lower BMI-for-age percentile score at postintervention, but this difference failed to reach the conventional level of statistical significance for a two-tailed test, standardized β = −.35 (p = .096).

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: The Recipe 4 Success preventive intervention targeted inter-related factors that are likely to be compromised by living in poverty and predict long-term health and well-being. This study found statistically significant postintervention between-group differences in aspects of parents’ sensitive scaffolding, responsive food parenting practices, toddlers’ self-regulation, and healthy eating habits. As such, this study informs our understanding of how to design and implement more effective two-generation preventive interventions to support families with toddlers and young children living in poverty.

sec.title: Recipe 4 Success intervention effects
sec.p: This randomized controlled trial of Recipe 4 Success found that parents were able to apply what they had learned in the context of cooking with toddlers to other tasks in which they helped their toddlers master a new skill. In particular, compared to control group parents, intervention parents exhibited higher levels of our core parenting behaviors (e.g., describing their toddlers’ behavior to maintain focus and concentration; reflecting and expanding on what their toddlers said or did to demonstrate interest and promote language development; providing specific praise for persistence and effort; and giving meaningful concrete choices to foster investment and autonomy). Compared to control group parents, intervention parents also exhibited higher levels of learning support, in general. Prior research demonstrates that sensitive parenting reduces the stress children experience, dampening activation of the hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal axis and reducing allostatic load, including weight gain (Evans, 2003). Indeed, in families in which there are high levels of sensitive parenting, relations between cumulative environmental risk and children’s allostatic load are reduced substantially (Evans et al., 2007). Such parenting in the early years of life is integral to a nurturing care framework intended to subvert the effects of racism on the development of child obesity (Skouteris et al., 2020). The results of this trial suggest that providing parents with the right support at the right time may be one of the most effective means of promoting resilience among families living in poverty.

Recipe 4 Success also altered food parenting practices: It not only increased the proportion of responsive and noncoercive strategies parents tried as they introduced their toddlers to novel healthy foods but also the sensitivity with which parents used those strategies. When parents provide nutritious options but respect children’s autonomy by letting them decide what to eat, children are more likely to maintain healthy relationships with food and are less likely to gain excessive weight (Vollmer & Mobley, 2013). Like other preventive interventions that have focused on responsive food parenting practices (Harvey-Berino & Rourke, 2003), Recipe 4 Success may help shift parent–child interactions around food in a way that supports toddlers’ self-regulation and healthy eating habits.

This trial found that Recipe 4 Success promoted multiple dimensions of toddlers’ self-regulation, including the abilities to delay gratification and resist temptation, to concentrate and pay attention, and to refrain from pursuing their own goals and comply with parental requests. Compared to families in the control group, intervention parents also perceived their toddlers to exhibit less negative emotionality and to have fewer eating and sleep problems. In most biological systems, change is most likely to happen before canalization occurs (Blair & Raver, 2012), suggesting that self-regulation will be most malleable during early childhood. The fact that self-regulation by ages 5–6 predicts diverse and important outcomes going forward suggests considerable rank-order stability across middle childhood, adolescence, and adulthood (Moffitt et al., 2011). Because of positive and negative developmental cascades, small differences in early childhood can become magnified over time. Recipe 4 Success represents an addition to the relatively small cadre of preventive interventions that improve self-regulation at such an important period in development as the toddler years (Murray et al., 2015).

Finally, the results of this trial showed that Recipe 4 Success produced changes in toddlers’ healthy eating habits. It is encouraging that, compared to families in the control group, parents in Recipe 4 Success were more likely to involve their toddlers in preparing meals and snacks after the intervention had ended. When children help prepare healthy foods, they are more likely to eat those foods, and when families cook and eat at home, children are more likely to have a normal weight (Knai et al., 2006). We found that, at the end of the 12-week intervention, toddlers who participated in Recipe 4 Success, compared to usual practice Early Head Start home visits, were eating more healthy foods each day. Moreover, when toddlers with overweight/obesity participated in Recipe 4 Success, rather than usual practice Early Head Start home visits, they may be more likely to have a lower BMI. Although that difference was not statistically significant (p = .096) due to the smaller subsample of toddlers with overweight/obesity at baseline, the intervention effect size, standardized β = −.35, was considerably larger than the intervention effect sizes, d = .10–.20, typically found in other interventions targeting childhood obesity (Kerr et al., 2019). Because healthy eating habits in early childhood are some of the strongest predictors of adult diet (Craigie et al., 2011), changes in this domain, if sustained and built upon, could have life-long implications for physical health.

sec.title: Cumulative evidence of effectiveness
sec.p: In the first trial (Nix et al., 2021) and in this second trial, Recipe 4 Success produced statistically significant intervention effects in parents’ sensitive scaffolding, responsive food parenting practices, toddlers’ self-regulation, and healthy eating habits. Together, these two trials substantiate the value of our community-based participatory research approach to working with racially and ethnically diverse families living in poverty (Nix, 2020).

The major difference between the results of these two trials was the magnitude of the intervention effects: The first trial produced medium-to-large intervention effect sizes, whereas this second trial produced small-to-medium intervention effect sizes. Aside from random variation across samples, this difference could be a result of the fact that, in the first trial, all of our Early Head Start partners helped create the preventive intervention (Nix, 2020). As a result, Early Head Start administrators and home visitors were more familiar with the rationale behind the different components of the curriculum and may have felt greater investment in implementing them well. This difference in intervention effect sizes could have been due to a greater emphasis in this second trial on the four core parenting behaviors, including adding two lessons devoted solely to teaching those behaviors. Perhaps, by focusing on these core parenting behaviors more, we overtaxed both home visitors and parents and diluted the impact of other critical messages and skills. This difference in intervention effect sizes also could be a result of changes in some of the featured recipes. In the first trial, we included several recipes that were child friendly and reasonably healthy, such as English muffin pizzas and peanut butter-chocolate chip granola bars. In contrast, in this second trial, all of our recipes were child friendly but only included WIC-approved ingredients, such as a vegetable omelet and pumpkin soup. It could be that our recipes in the first trial were better aligned with the kind of change families were ready or willing to make, and our recipes in the second trial were too different from current and preferred diets to be readily embraced, thus dampening enthusiasm for the lessons overall.

Although the current Recipe 4 Success intervention effects are smaller than those of the previous trial, they are as large as those found in most other two-generation preventive interventions for families with young children (Filene et al., 2013; Murray et al., 2015). In general, effect sizes for preventive interventions are smaller than effect sizes in clinical treatments because preventive interventions inevitably include families who may not require the support provided, thereby reducing group differences. Importantly, however, even small-to-medium intervention effects can lead to substantial and meaningful long-term change, especially when intervention effects set in motion self-perpetuating virtuous cycles that give children the support and skills they will need to navigate the challenges they may encounter.

sec.title: Enhancing the effectiveness of home visit programs
sec.p: Recipe 4 Success was designed to be embedded within Early Head Start home visits to take advantage of the therapeutic relationships that already had been formed and to enhance the ability of the national program to effectuate change. By relying on evidence-based usual-practice Early Head Start home visits as the comparison condition, this trial of Recipe 4 Success suggests a refined model for how home visit programs can be organized and optimized. Although following one longer evidence-based curriculum, such as Parents as Teachers (Wagner et al., 2002), has been effective overall, adding a series of shorter term evidence-based curricula that are timed with developmental transitions and focused on specific milestones might boost program benefits and yield even better outcomes for children.

There are several advantages to such an approach. First, many of the preventive interventions with the strongest evidence of efficacy, such as Playing and Learning Strategies, are implemented over a relatively circumscribed period of about 12 weeks (Landry et al., 2008). This kind of focused attention on a limited set of learning objectives may have advantages for both home visitors and families. Second, these preventive interventions with the strongest evidence are the result of countless hours of planning, piloting, and testing. They most likely represent superior lessons to what overtaxed home visitors can create on their own, between appointments with the families in their caseloads, based on looser guidance from broader curricula. Third, learning to implement multiple brief evidence-based preventive interventions with fidelity could build professional capacity and expertise among home visitors, which could generalize to all of their work. In addition, there may be less burnout among home visitors as they feel more effective in actually helping the families they work with (Maslach et al., 2001). Fourth, families may appreciate more variety in lesson content, and different families may respond to some approaches more than others.

Current home visiting programs, such as Early Head Start, with their established infrastructure in most communities, may serve as an unrivaled platform with which to widely disseminate the best preventive interventions. Although including multiple new evidence-based preventive interventions within home visiting programs would require either more resources or a re-allocation of current resources, such costs may represent a small percentage of overall expenditures. In our case, it costs about $4800 to provide Early Head Start home visits to one family for eightmonths, which is the average length of participation, and considerably more when families remain enrolled for a longer proportion of the three-plus years they are eligible (Corso et al., 2022). The one-time cost of providing Recipe 4 Success for 12 weeks was about $300 per family: $100 for food; less than $100 dollars for materials, such as curriculum manuals and recipe books; and about $100 for the home visitor trainings and supervision. All other costs, such as home visitor salary and benefits, were the same regardless of which curricula Early Head Start programs were implementing.

Compared to no home visits at all, Early Head Start improves parent and child functioning, with statistically significant intervention effects of .09–.20 (Love et al., 2005). The results of this trial suggest that, compared to usual practice Early Head Start, a preventive intervention like Recipe 4 Success could enhance critical dimensions of family functioning and child development even more, with additional statistically significant intervention effects of .16–.33.

sec.title: Study strengths and limitations
sec.p: In testing the efficacy of Recipe 4 Success, this study had several strengths. It included a racially and ethnically diverse sample of families, most of whom were living in poverty in a broad cross-section of communities. This study has high external validity because Recipe 4 Success was implemented by Early Head Start home visitors in the context of their regular work with families. This study has high internal validity because families were randomly assigned to condition within home visitor caseloads. Intervention and control group differences depended on the curriculum only, and any contamination across conditions would work against finding intervention effects. In our design, the efficacy of Recipe 4 Success was compared to the evidence-based curricula Early Head Start centers were currently using: Our intervention effects were in addition to those already brought about by Early Head Start on its own. To gauge those intervention effects, this study included multiple observational measures, assessed in a variety of contexts that required generalization of intervention lessons (i.e., parents used what they learned while making an omelette to teach their toddlers how to bowl). In addition, ratings of parents and children were made by different teams of project interviewers and research assistants who were unaware of the study condition. Finally, this study produced a similar pattern of findings to a previous trial (Nix et al., 2021), providing evidence of high replicability. Although original discovery is important, replication may have greater scientific merit and public policy value (Ioannidis, 2018).

This study also had notable limitations. First, although this trial included 47 Latinx families (19% of the sample), it excluded an additional 36 families who spoke only Spanish. We initially tried to accommodate these families, but soon realized that virtually no aspect of participating in the trial was comparable for English- and Spanish-speaking families. Important differences for Spanish-speaking families included the cultural compatibility of the suggested changes to parent–child interactions, the appeal of featured recipes, instability in housing that comes with being even more marginalized in the United States, the perceived safety of sharing family information with unfamiliar adults in an unpredictable political climate, and the experience and availability of project interviewers and research assistants who were fluent in Spanish and could conduct assessments and code video recordings of parent–child interactions. Second, this study tested postintervention between-group differences, not baseline-to-postintervention change. For some parent and toddler outcomes, mean change across time and across conditions was quite small. This could reflect developmental processes or experience. For example, parents may be less likely to engage in high levels of learning support behaviors as their toddlers mature and become more familiar with tasks. What parents learn in Recipe 4 Success might help slow a normative decline and/or shift rank-order stability, lessening the impact of baseline functioning on postintervention functioning. Third, this study tested postintervention between-group differences without investigating the therapeutic mechanisms that might explain how those differences came to be.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS AND IMPLICATIONS
sec.p: Accumulating research documents the long-term consequences of growing up in poverty, especially among children of color (Iruka et al., 2022). It is critical we change public policy to reduce class- and race-based structural inequities too many children face, and it is critical we refine our two-generation preventive interventions for families so they are as effective as can be.

This study demonstrated how the Recipe 4 Success preventive intervention can help promote parents’ sensitive scaffolding and responsive food parenting practices, as well as toddlers’ self-regulation and healthy eating habits. In this way, we can begin to ameliorate family-level risks that are endemic to living in poverty, and we can begin to inculcate protective factors associated with long-term health and well-being.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
ack.p: This study was funded by the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (National Institutes of Health grant R01HD081361) to the University of Wisconsin-Madison. The Recipe 4 Success intervention was developed with funding from the National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences (National Institutes of Health grant UL Tr000127 to the Clinical and Translational Science Institute of Pennsylvania State University), the Social Sciences Research Institute of Pennsylvania State University, and the Edna Bennett Pierce Prevention Research Center of Pennsylvania State University. The intervention was the result of a community-based participatory research collaboration involving Mark Feinberg, Lori Francis, Sukhdeep Gill, Robert Nix, and Cynthia Stifter, and numerous Early Head Start administrators and home visitors from Pennsylvania. We are grateful to our community partners for this trial from Wisconsin and Pennsylvania, and we are grateful to all participating families.

sec.title: DATA AVAILABILITY STATEMENT
sec.p: This study was preregistered at clinicaltrials.gov, NCT03958214. Intervention materials, data, and analytic code are available upon reasonable request from the first author, at robert.nix@wisc.edu.
